name: Toggle
htmlBanner:
Toggle

A toggle is used to switch between two possible states, commonly used for turning on/off certain features or views.

Accessibility.html:
Overview

Momentum has keyboard operation built into all of its components, improving the experience for visually impaired users and other users who operate using the keyboard.

Keyboard interaction

Each toggle is in the tab order. Pressing Enter or Space

Controls

TAB to move focus to next element
SPACE or RETURN/ENTER to activate and inactivate toggle
SHIFT + TAB to move focus to the previous key

Controls

TAB to move focus to next element
SPACE or RETURN/ENTER to activate and inactivate toggle
SHIFT + TAB to move focus to the previous key

Momentum’s default toggle uses both color and text to indicate on or off state. Momentum also added a checkmark with the new update to the toggle’s “on” state, so that the component’s on/off state can be distinguished without relying just on use of color.

Screen reader

When toggles are implemented, the label will require additional context to be announced by the screen reader. Toggle must inform a user of the Name (visible label OR screen reader text) , Role (Toggle), and State (On/off) The group label must only be announced when first navigating into the group. The accessibility label should comes from the visible label text on the Toggle. Align the accessibility label (used for assistive technology devices like screen readers) with the visible label text. WCAG References 1.3.1: Info and Relationships (Level A) 4.1.2: Name, Role, Value (Level A)

aria-label set on the element with role switch. When on, the Toggle element has state aria-checked set to true. When off, the Toggle element has state aria-checked set to false. If the Toggle element is an HTML input[type="checkbox"], it uses the HTML checked attribute instead of the aria-checked property. If the presentation includes additional descriptive static text relevant to a Toggle or Toggle group, it has the property aria-describedby

Layout

Sizing

Default toggle and label height is 24px. Compact toggle height is 16px, 20px for the label.

Spacing

Toggle should have minimum of 8px padding top and bottom, and minimum of 12px spacing between toggles. e and label height is 24px. Compact toggle height is 16px, 20px for the label.

Voicemails

Inbox setting

To change the volume of your notification sounds, go to Audio.

8

24px Minimum

Vertical spacing

Toggles should have minimum of 8px padding around the component. In this example, 8px spacing is between the title text and the toggle.

Use Case

Toggle switches are digital on/off switches. They prompt users to choose between two mutually exclusive options and always have a default value. Toggles should provide immediate results, giving users the freedom to control their preferences as needed.

When to use

Used to quickly switch between two possible states.
Used for actions that occur immediately after the user press to on/off certain feature or view. Most common use cases are “on/off” use cases.

When NOT to use

When the two states are not opposites or where the alternate setting is not intuitively obvious. For example, if the two options are “Allow single sign-on” and “Use two-factor authentication,” these options are not common opposites. It will be unclear to the user what the impact of switching from one to the other. In a case like this, use radio buttons instead.

Types

Default Toggle w/ Label
Default Toggle
Compact Toggle w/ Label
Compact Togle

Dos and Dont’s

Use ppropriate size

Toggle is already using checkmark icon that clearly communicate on/off status.

Do not switch the checkmark to any other checkmark or icons in our icon library.

For longer labels, it is recommended to have the label separate layer from the toggle, on the left side of the toggle, not on the toggle label.

Although the label will wrap and designers are able to use longer label, it is recommended to use separate description text for longer labels instead of Toggle label.

Content

Toggle Label

A label for a toggle describes what the control will do when switched. Try to include all necessary information in the label. Never use the words “On” or “Off” in a toggle label. Label must be specific.
Words like “Enabled” or “Disabled” are fine as long as they add to clarity but must include a header.

Toggle Label length

Keep labels for toggle switches short and direct. Toggle labels should be 1-4 words max.
If more information is needed, use description text or a tooltip.

Should is use a verb?

Because toggles naturally show a persistent state of a thing (a noun or proper noun) being "on" or "off." A verb is usually unnecessary, but sometimes, using the label as a verb can improve clarity. Just keep consistent with verbs or nouns if in a group.
Avoid verb phrases like "turn on/off thing" in toggle labels, as it's redundant and can clutter the UI.

Talk directly to the user, if needed

Describe toggles using only the names of features or settings or what those features and settings will do. If you must refer to a user, do so sparingly and use the second person, "you/your." Talk to the user, not as them.

Usable Examples

Webex

Webex Assist

Webex Engage

Related Components

Radio Button

If you need single selection from two or more options that are mutually exclusive, use Radio

Checkbox

If you need multiple selection from a set of options, use Checkbox

Button

Short description of the related component and how it pertains to the current component.
